title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Data visualisation plays a crucial role in modern decision-making by transforming complex datasets into accessible visual narratives. In an era where data-driven decisions shape industries, effective visualisations help stakeholders quickly grasp insights and patterns, leading to informed and strategic choices.By turning abstract numbers into visual stories, data visualisation enhances understanding, fosters communication, and drives impactful actions.






Tip



In this session we will mostly focus on non-spatial visualisation, but many of the principles also apply to the times when you will be creating maps to be part of your stories.




The main purposes of enhancing your narrative with data can be categorised into three key areas:

Facilitating quick understanding of complex information.
Identifying patterns, trends, and outliers.
Guiding decision-makers towards strategic actions aligned with your objectives.

Additionally, the way you share your visualisations‚Äîwhether through static reports, interactive dashboards, or embedded in web pages‚Äîwill influence the tool selection. title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Exploring vs.¬†Presenting

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt run before you can walk‚Äù

Start simple and gradually build complexity. In data visualisation, it‚Äôs tempting to jump straight to advanced tools or sophisticated designs, but this can lead to confusion and inefficiency if the basics are not well understood. Begin with simple exploratory analyses to understand your data, then progressively refine and enhance your visualisations as your message becomes clearer and your narrative more defined.


Exploratory data visualisation
is about discovering insights, identifying patterns, and asking new questions. It is most useful during the initial stages of data analysis when the goal is to understand the data and its structure. At this stage, it‚Äôs not about perfection but about exploration and iteration.



Explanatory data visualisation
on the other hand, is about communicating a specific message or insight clearly to an audience. It involves polishing the visualisation, ensuring accuracy, and crafting a narrative that guides the viewer to the intended conclusion.


Learning when to switch from exploration to presentation is key to managing efforts effectively. Investing time in refining and polishing a visualisation is only worthwhile once the message is clear and impactful.

Principles of Data Visualisation

Gestalt Principles
The Gestalt principles originate from a psychological theory developed by German psychologists in the early 20th century. These principles explain how humans naturally perceive visual elements as organized patterns or wholes, rather than as separate components (see Wagemans 2012). In data visualisation, Gestalt principles help designers arrange information in a way that is easily understood and visually appealing. By leveraging these principles, data visualisations can guide viewers to see relationships, hierarchies, and narratives within the data more intuitively.








Principle
Description
Example




Proximity
Elements that are close to each other are perceived as a group.



Similarity
Items that share visual characteristics are seen as related.



Continuity
The eye follows lines and curves smoothly without abrupt changes.



Closure
Incomplete shapes are perceived as complete wholes.



Connectedness
Items connected by lines or other visual cues are seen as related.



Colour
Utilises hues and shades to convey meaning and hierarchy.



White Space
Strategic use of empty space to enhance readability and focus.




These (and many other) principles guide visual perception and interpretation by leveraging the brain‚Äôs natural tendencies to group similar elements, follow continuous lines, and fill in gaps to perceive complete shapes. By applying these principles, designers can direct the viewer‚Äôs attention, create visual hierarchies, and improve the overall user experience. This strategic arrangement of visual elements not only enhances comprehension but also makes complex data more approachable and meaningful.


Choosing the Right Chart
Matching data types to the most effective visualisation is essential for conveying the intended message clearly and accurately. Different types of data‚Äîsuch as categorical, numerical, and temporal data‚Äîrequire different visualisation approaches to effectively highlight patterns, trends, and relationships.

Categorical data, which represents discrete groups or categories, is best displayed using bar charts, pie charts, or stacked column charts for comparing proportions or frequencies.
Numerical data, especially when showing distributions or relationships, is effectively visualised through histograms, scatter plots, or line graphs.
Temporal data, which involves time series or sequences, is well-suited to line charts or area charts to show trends over time.

Selecting the right chart type enhances the narrative and helps the audience interpret the data more intuitively.

Misleading graphs (e.g., truncated axes, improper scaling).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
1. The Spatial Dimension

The Logic of ‚ÄúWhere‚Äù: Focuses on geometry, distance, and density.
Key Question: How does the physical arrangement of assets (buildings, parks, roads) determine urban performance?
Core Concept: Social Physics. Just like gravity, ‚Äúmass‚Äù (high-density jobs or housing) exerts a pull on the surrounding area.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
2. The Relational Dimension

The Logic of ‚ÄúConnection‚Äù: Focuses on topology and network hierarchy.
Key Question: How is the city ‚Äúwired‚Äù? Is it about how far you are in meters, or how many turns you are from the main network?
Core Concept: Graph Theory. The city as nodes and edges.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
3. The Temporal Dimension

The Logic of ‚ÄúWhen‚Äù: Focuses on change, evolution, and path dependency.
Key Question: How did the city get here, and how fast is it changing?
Core Concept: Dynamics. Recognizing that an urban intervention today might take 10 years to show its true impact (delays).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
4. The Systemic Dimension

The Logic of ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù: Focuses on causality and interdependencies.
Key Question: What are the unintended consequences? If we improve transport, does it inadvertently raise rents and displace the people it was meant to help?
Core Concept: Feedback Loops. Circular causality where an output of a system becomes an input for the next cycle.

Predictive Certainty. Because it is stochastic (probabilistic), it gives you a range of ‚Äúpossible futures‚Äù rather than a single definitive answer.

System Archetypes

Balancing & LimitsUnintended FeedbackResource & Power Loops



Limits to Growth: A tech-hub grows fast until housing prices drive out the talent, hitting a plateau.
Eroding Goals: Reducing environmental targets because the current infrastructure ‚Äúcannot handle‚Äù the cost of meeting them.
Growth and Underinvestment: Demand for public transit grows, but the city delays purchasing new trains, leading to a collapse in service quality.




Fixes that Fail: Widening a road to fix traffic leads to ‚Äúinduced demand,‚Äù creating more traffic than before.
Shifting the Burden: Using temporary ‚Äúband-aid‚Äù repairs on aging water pipes instead of replacing the fundamental infrastructure.
Escalation: Two neighboring districts compete to offer the lowest taxes to attract firms, eventually bankrupting their own public services.




Tragedy of the Commons: Unregulated groundwater extraction by individual buildings leading to the sinking of the entire city‚Äôs foundation.
Success to the Successful: High-income neighborhoods receive the best schools, which increases property values and further concentrates educational funding there.
Accidental Adversaries: A transit agency and a housing department both try to optimize their own KPIs, but end up blocking each other‚Äôs long-term goals.

title: Course Guide
text:
Content
This course introduces students to the concepts, technologies, governance models, and socio-spatial implications of Smart Cities. It critically examines how digital technologies, data, and urban analytics are applied to address urban challenges such as sustainability, mobility, climate adaptation, inclusion and quality of life. Through a project-based approach, students work in groups to analyse a real or simulated urban case, develop a Smart Cities solution, and reflect on ethical, social and governance dimensions. In this course, the student will gain fundamental theoretical and practical knowledge to understand smart cities, including the relationship to the sustainability debate applies knowledge and skills to a real-life case study involving local communities in the indicator analysis, development of Smart City planning solutions and policy recommendations for the built environment. Be able to critically reflect on Smart City concepts and communicate the results of Smart City strategies to stakeholders. This course utilises acquired knowledge from previous and parallel running courses, such as the advanced methods course, ethics in research, data analysis in GIS, and urban policies, and adds to it the component of smart sustainable cities and the human factor.

text:
I‚Äôve spent the last decade at the intersection of data science and the built environment. Early on, I realized that while infrastructure is static, human behavior is dynamic. This led me to the Space Syntax approach‚Äîessentially using data-driven, graph-based analysis to understand multi-scale networks. It allowed me to bridge the gap between rigorous academic theory and the practical realities of urban consultancy.
In terms of technical scale, my experience is quite broad. I‚Äôve managed everything from high-frequency IoT sensor data for real-time indoor movement to architecting the tracking of entire city bus networks modelling scenarios. I‚Äôve applied these insights to everything from local ‚Äòurban acupuncture‚Äô strategies to large-scale masterplans, always focusing on how we can use data to measure social benefits. My work has taken me across the globe‚Äîfrom Colombia to Australia, London, and now Madrid‚Äîwhich has given me a deep appreciation for the cultural nuances required to work effectivily with multinational teams.
Inevitably, working on European urban development leads you to the Net-Zero agenda. Most recently, in 2024, I led a team of eight researchers at the Norman Foster Institute to develop the Climate Action Plan for Athens. This was a major milestone where we had to harmonize environmental data,set plans for reaching carbon emission targets, and greening strategies into a compliant, actionable policy framework.
This work led me to what I call my ‚Äòprofessional obsession‚Äô: the link between environmental quality and human health outcomes. I‚Äôve realized that the environment‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs air quality, climate resilience, or the built landscape‚Äîis the primary driver of health inequalities. Over the last year, I‚Äôve been focusing on quantifying these links, moving from spectral analysis of country-wide information to advising on transport initiatives that prioritize health outcomes. I want to move beyond just ‚Äòcollecting data‚Äô to reducing the environmental inequalities that impact people‚Äôs lives.
That brings me here. I see this role at the EEA as the ideal next frontier. It‚Äôs the one place where I can combine data at scale, health implications, and European policy. I‚Äôve spent my career ‚Äòforcing‚Äô these elements to meet, and I‚Äôm eager to bring that integrated perspective to the Agency‚Äôs monitoring and evidence-gathering mission.



There are three primary reasons why I am sitting here today, ranging from the Agency‚Äôs unique mandate to the urgency of our current environmental timeline.

The Unique Intersection of Science and Policy First, from an institutional perspective, the EEA is unparalleled. There is truly no other organization in the world where high-level science, legislative policy, and ground-level implementation meet with such a rigorous and independent point of view. For a data professional, the opportunity to work within the Eionet framework‚Äîtranslating raw monitoring data into the evidence base that literally steers the European Green Deal‚Äîis the highest possible application of my skillset.
The Urgency of the Mission Second, on a personal level, I cannot think of a human challenge more pressing than the climate and biodiversity crisis. We saw in the State of the Environment Report (SOER) that while our frameworks are robust, far too few of our targets are currently on track for 2030. This reality doesn‚Äôt discourage me; it focuses me. I want to be part of the ‚Äòcourse correction,‚Äô using data to identify exactly where we are lagging and how we can accelerate progress toward climate neutrality.
The Scale of the Challenge Finally, I am genuinely excited by the sheer scale of the challenge. Moving from urban-scale projects to a pan-European monitoring mandate is a significant leap, but it is one I feel prepared for. I am at a stage in my career where I want to contribute at the highest level possible. I am confident that my experience in harmonizing fragmented data across borders and my focus on health outcomes can provide the Agency with the ‚Äòconnective tissue‚Äô needed to turn complex monitoring into actionable policy insights.




I view stress not as an individual burden to be hidden, but as a signal to recalibrate our collective focus. My approach to high-pressure situations‚Äîsuch as a tight reporting deadline for a major EEA indicator‚Äîis built on three pillars:

Above all, I am a team player. When pressure mounts, I believe in absolute transparency with my peers. I don‚Äôt ‚Äòhide‚Äô from the stress; I bring it to the table so we can address it together. By fostering a supportive environment early on, I ensure that when a crisis hits, the team feels comfortable speaking up about bottlenecks before they become failures.
(‚ÄòProject First‚Äô Mindset) My first instinct in a stressed scenario is to shift the focus from individual tasks to the overall project objective. I lead the team in a rapid prioritization exercise‚Äîidentifying ‚Äòmust-haves‚Äô versus ‚Äònice-to-haves‚Äô and playing to each person‚Äôs strengths. It‚Äôs an ‚Äòall hands on deck‚Äô approach where we reallocate resources dynamically to ensure the core mission is met, even if it means shifting secondary individual goals.
(Proactive Mentorship and Support Networks) I am a firm believer in keeping close mentors and a professional support network. I don‚Äôt wait for a crisis to build these relationships. By maintaining regular contact with mentors, I have a ‚Äòready-to-go‚Äô sounding board when stress hits. This means I can get high-level advice or a second opinion quickly, without needing a full debrief of the situation, allowing for faster decision-making under pressure.

Pros
Captures ‚ÄúEmergent Phenomena‚Äù and diversity; allows for the modeling of irrational or ‚Äúhuman‚Äù behaviors.

Cons
Computationally expensive; very difficult to ‚Äúvalidate‚Äù because small changes in rules can lead to wildly different outcomes.





What it lacks


Predictive Certainty. Because it is stochastic (probabilistic), it gives you a range of ‚Äúpossible futures‚Äù rather than a single definitive answer.

The ‚ÄúWicked‚Äù Problem

Urban challenges are not puzzles (with one right answer).
They are Wicked Problems:

They are interconnected: solving one creates another.
They have no ‚Äústopping rule‚Äù or perfect solution.
They are better or worse, not right or wrong.



Refer to Rittel and Webber‚Äôs definition 1973. Explain that in a smart city context, we often try to ‚Äúoptimize‚Äù things. But a city isn‚Äôt a machine to be optimized; it‚Äôs a wicked problem to be managed. For their assignments: help them see that their chosen problem (e.g., housing or pollution) is ‚Äúwicked‚Äù because it‚Äôs tied to a dozen other factors.
Key Characteristics of Wicked Problems:

No definitive formulation: The problem itself is hard to define.
No ‚Äústopping rule‚Äù: There‚Äôs no clear point at which you know it‚Äôs solved.
Solutions aren‚Äôt true/false: They are only ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad,‚Äù not objectively correct.
Irreversible consequences: Every attempt to solve it has lasting impacts, making ‚Äútrials count‚Äù.
Interconnectedness: Solving one part often creates or reveals other problems.

System Archetypes

Balancing & LimitsUnintended FeedbackResource & Power Loops



Limits to Growth: A tech-hub grows fast until housing prices drive out the talent, hitting a plateau.
Eroding Goals: Reducing environmental targets because the current infrastructure ‚Äúcannot handle‚Äù the cost of meeting them.
Growth and Underinvestment: Demand for public transit grows, but the city delays purchasing new trains, leading to a collapse in service quality.




Fixes that Fail: Widening a road to fix traffic leads to ‚Äúinduced demand,‚Äù creating more traffic than before.
Shifting the Burden: Using temporary ‚Äúband-aid‚Äù repairs on aging water pipes instead of replacing the fundamental infrastructure.
Escalation: Two neighboring districts compete to offer the lowest taxes to attract firms, eventually bankrupting their own public services.




Tragedy of the Commons: Unregulated groundwater extraction by individual buildings leading to the sinking of the entire city‚Äôs foundation.
Success to the Successful: High-income neighborhoods receive the best schools, which increases property values and further concentrates educational funding there.
Accidental Adversaries: A transit agency and a housing department both try to optimize their own KPIs, but end up blocking each other‚Äôs long-term goals.

Decision Support Tools are the nervous system. They take the data from our models and present it so a Mayor, a Planner, or a Citizen can say ‚ÄúIf we do X, then Y happens.‚Äù
Crucial point: A good DST doesn‚Äôt hide complexity; it manages it.

In an urban context, a dashboard shouldn‚Äôt just be a ‚Äúreport card‚Äù of the past. It should be a ‚Äúflight simulator‚Äù for the future.
Example: A dashboard that shows current CO2 levels is a viz; a dashboard that lets you ‚Äúdelete‚Äù a parking lot and see the CO2 drop in real-time is a Decision Support Tool.

Just because a dashboard is ‚Äúshiny‚Äù or 3D doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs accurate.

Truncated Realities
What is not being measured? (e.g., social capital, happiness).

Cognitive Biases
How ‚ÄúVisual Narratives‚Äù can accidentally (or intentionally) nudge decisions the wrong way.

In Smart Cities, there is a risk of ‚ÄúTechnological Solutionism.‚Äù If it‚Äôs on a high-res screen, people tend to believe it‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Truth.‚Äù
As curators of these tools, the students must ensure the visualization doesn‚Äôt lie about the model‚Äôs uncertainty.
